facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court from Bombay High Court judgment dated 9th March 1943 in Second Appeal No. 717 of 1940.

anchor.surface_text: APPEAL from the High Court of Judicature at Bombay Appeal No. XXXVII of 1949. This was an appeal from a judgment and decree of the Bombay High Court dated 9th March, 1943, in Second Appeal No. 717 of 1940, varying the decree of the Assistant Judge, Ahmedabad, in Appeal No. 173 of 1936 reversing the decree of the joint Sub-Judge, Ahmedabad, in Suit No. 830 of 1933.

facts.text: Suit No. 830 of 1933 filed by respondent firm in July 1933 for ejectment of survey Nos. 222, 223, 225, 226 in Rampura, Ahmedabad district and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which this appeal arises was filed by the respondent firm in ejectment to recover possession of survey Nos. 222, 223, 225 and 226 situate in Rampura in Ahmedabad district and for mesne profits, as early as July, 1933, and during its 17 years span of life it had a somewhat chequered career.

facts.text: Bhankoda talukdari estate in Viramgam taluka, Ahmedabad district, jointly owned by several talukdars, comprises twelve villages including Rampura.

anchor.surface_text: There is a talukdari estate called the Bhankoda estate in Viramgam taluka in Ahmedabad district. It is jointly owned by several talukdars in different shares and comprises twelve villages one of which is Rampura in which the suit lands are situate.

facts.text: Government Resolution No. 8170 dated 30th August 1912 took Bhankoda estate under Government management under section 28 of Gujarat Talukdars Act.

anchor.surface_text: By Government Resolution No. 8170, dated 30th August 1912, the estate was taken under Government management under section 28 of the Gujarat Talukdars Act  Bombay Act VI of 1888 .

facts.text: Shah Manilal Maganlal and Bros., predecessors of appellant, desired permanent lease of survey Nos. 228, 225, 226 for ginning factory.

anchor.surface_text: The firm of Shah Manilal Maganlal and Bros.  predecessors in interest of the appellant  de- sired to erect a ginning factory on survey Nos. 228, 225, and 226 and with that object approached the Talukdari Set- tlement Officer for a permanent lease of these survey num- bers.

facts.text: Application by Shah Manilal Maganlal on 9th December 1916 for permanent lease of survey numbers at Rs. 290 annual rent.

anchor.surface_text: On 9th December 1916 an application was made by Shah Manilal Maganlal in writing signed by him to the Talukdari Settlement Officer offering to take a permanent lease of the above mentioned survey numbers on an annual rental of Rs. 290 for the purpose of erecting a ginning factory.

facts.text: Talukdari Settlement Officer provisionally accepted offer on 12th July 1917.

anchor.surface_text: On 12th July 1917 the said officer accepted provisionally this offer after taking into consideration the objections raised by some of the talukdars in respect of the grant of a lease.

facts.text: Government sanction by Resolution No. 10795 dated 5th September 1917.

anchor.surface_text: By Resolution No. 10795 of 1917 dated 5th September 1917 the Government of Bombay granted the requisite sanction.

facts.text: Binding agreement to lease effected between Talukdari Settlement Officer and Shah Manilal Maganlal with Government sanction.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that a binding agreement to lease the survey numbers in question was effected between the Talukdari Settlement Officer and Shah Manilal Maganlal with the sanc- tion of the Government.

facts.text: Lessee took possession soon after agreement and erected ginning factory, pressing factory, bungalow, engine rooms.

anchor.surface_text: Though a draft of a formal deed of lease was prepared, no such document was formally executed or registered for reasons which it is not necessary to state herein. Soon after the agreement the lessee took possession of the survey numbers in suit and put up thereupon a ginning and a pressing factory, a bungalow, engine rooms and other structures.

facts.text: Lessee tendered agreed rent to Talukdari Settlement Officer who received it for about two years.

anchor.surface_text: He tendered the agreed rent to the Talukdari Settlement Officer who received it from him. He continued receiving it for about two years when the estate was re- leased from the management of the Government and came under the management of the talukdars.

facts.text: Possessory mortgage on 4th May 1924 by Shah Manilal Maganlal of ginning factory to defendant for Rs. 1,40,000.

anchor.surface_text: On 4th May, 1924, a possessory mortgage of the ginning factory along with all its buildings was effected by Shah Manilal Maganlal in the sum of Rs. 1,40,000 in favour of the defendant.

facts.text: Defendant and plaintiffs acquired rights in property during 1924-25; defendant as mortgagee, plaintiffs as ijaradar and assignee of mortgage rights.

anchor.surface_text: The two contestants in the suit, the defendant and the plaintiffs, acquired their rights in this property during the years 1924-25. The defend ant came in as a mortgagee as above stated, while the plaintiffs came in as ijaradar and assign- ees of certain mortgage rights.

facts.text: Appellant purchased equity of redemption of suit property at court auction in 1933.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1933 the appellant purchased the equity of redemption of the suit property at a court auction and became vested with all the rights of Mani- lal Maganlal in this property, the value of which has not been estimated in the neighbourhood of Rs. 38,000.

facts.text: Plaint admitted lease negotiated between Shah Manilal and Talukdari Settlement Officer for survey numbers at Rs. 290 annual rent, but claimed no formal registered lease so trespassers.

anchor.surface_text: In the 2nd and 3rd paragraphs of the plaint it was admitted that in .the course of the correspondence with the Government of Bombay a lease was negotiated between the firm of Shah Manilal Maganlal and the Talukari Settlement Officer in respect of the survey numbers in dispute for a period of fifty years at an annual rental of Rs. 290, but it was stated that because Manilal Maganlal did not execute a formal registered lease they were in possession as trespassers.

facts.text: Joint Sub-Judge decreed suit for plaintiffs finding no written lease.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge decreed the suit on the finding that as no written lease was forthcoming it should be deemed to be non-existent.

facts.text: Assistant Judge on 27th April 1940 allowed defendant's appeal, held section 53-A applies.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Judge allowed the appeal on 27th April, 1940. He held that the plaintiffs had failed to establish their right to maintain the suit either as ijaradars or as assign- ees of mortgage rights.

facts.text: Bombay High Court on 9th March 1943 allowed plaintiffs' second appeal in part, decreed for survey Nos. 223 and 225.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the appeal and modified the decree of the Assistant Judge. It decreed the plaintiffs suit in respect of survey Nos. 223 and 225 and dismissed the suit in respect of survey Nos. 222 and 226,

facts.text: Supreme Court held defendant entitled to protection under section 53-A of Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the learned Assist- ant Judge rightly dismissed the plaintiffs suit and the High Court was in error in interfering with that decision in second appeal.

facts.text: Plaintiffs received rent up to 31st July 1932 admitted in plaint.

anchor.surface_text: In the 8th paragraph it was said that the plaintiffs received the amount of the lease up to 31st July 1932 and that no notice was necessary to be given, the position of the defendant being that of a trespasser.
under section 28 of the Gujarat Talukdars Act  Bombay Act VI of 1888 .

issues.text: whether the plaintiff firm has proved its title to maintain the present suit in ejectment against the defendant

anchor.surface_text: The principal questions canvassed in this appeal are, whether the plaintiff firm has proved its title to maintain the present suit in ejectment against the defendant, and whether the defendant is entitled to the benefit of the provisions of sec. 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act.

issues.text: whether the defendant is entitled to the benefit of the provisions of sec. 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act

anchor.surface_text: the defendant, and whether the defendant is entitled to the benefit of the provisions of sec. 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act. The question as to the maintainability of the suit against the defendant without a proper notice was raised before the High Court but permission to argue it was refused because the matter had not been raised in either of the lower Courts.

anchor.surface_text: It-may also be observed that an agreement of lease creating a present demise but number registered is admissible under S. 49 of the Indian Registra- tion Act as evidence of part performance and Ex. 181 is secondary evidence of that agreement.

arguments.claim: Formal lease not necessary for s53A; agreement in writing sufficient

anchor.surface_text: A formal lease is number necessary to attract the application of S. 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act. All that is required is that an agreement in writing signed by the transferor can be gath- ered from the evidence.

holdings.text: The learned Assistant Judge rightly dismissed the plaintiffs suit and the High Court was in error in interfering with that decision in second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the learned Assist- ant Judge rightly dismissed the plaintiffs suit and the High Court was in error in interfering with that decision in second appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All conditions of section 53-A TPA satisfied: written signed agreement evidenced by Ex. 181, ascertainable terms, part performance via possession/rent, willingness to perform.

holdings.text: The defendant has fulfilled both the conditions necessary to attract the application of the section [53-A] in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the defendant has fulfilled both the companydi- tions necessary to attract the application of the section in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Writing signed by TSO/Govt, terms clear from Ex181, possession taken, acts in furtherance (factory), rent paid, willing to perform.

holdings.text: Ex. 181 is good secondary evidence of the agreement of lease.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that Ex. 181 is good secondary evidence of the agreement of lease, there can then be number hesitation in holding that by an offer and an acceptance made in writing...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reliable govt record; primary not produced despite notice; plaintiff admitted correspondence knowledge; recites offer/acceptance.

holdings.text: By an offer and an acceptance made in writing and signed by the respective parties an agreement was completed between the Talukdari Settlement Officer and the predecessor in interest of the defendant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex181 details signed application (9 Dec 1916), provisional acceptance (12 Jul 1917), govt sanction (5 Sep 1917).

holdings.text: The terms of the contract can be fairly deduced from the recitals of this document [Ex181]: permanent lease at Rs. 290 per annum, terms revisable after 50 years.

anchor.surface_text: The only important clause with which we are companycerned in the present case is as to the nature of the tenancy. It is clearly recited therein that the lease was to be of a permanent character and the terms as regards rental companyld be revised after a period of fifty years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit recitals in Ex181 provide reasonable certainty.

holdings.text: The lessee took possession in part-performance of the agreement.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Possession post-agreement; structures erected (ginning factory etc.); prior tenant possession resolved.

holdings.text: Acceptance of rent by Talukdari Settlement Officer and successors shows possession in part performance; plaintiff admitted receiving lease amount up to 31st July 1932.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff in para. 6 of the plaint in unambiguous terms admitted that he received the amount of the lease up to 31st July, 1932, in respect of the survey numbers in dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Continuous tender/payment to TSO, manager, ijaradars; plaint para 6/8 admissions refer to the agreement.

holdings.text: The transferee has performed or is willing to perform his part of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant and his predecessor in interest were willing to perform their part of the company- tract. As a matter of fact, they have performed the whole of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rent paid fully; only formal registered lease remains from transferor.

holdings.text: An agreement of lease creating a present demise but not registered is admissible under S. 49 of the Indian Registration Act as evidence of part performance.

anchor.surface_text: It-may also be observed that an agreement of lease creating a present demise but number registered is admissible under S. 49 of the Indian Registra- tion Act as evidence of part performance and Ex. 181 is secondary evidence of that agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s49 Reg Act to unregistered writing for part perf evidence.

holdings.text: A formal lease is not necessary to attract the application of S. 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act. All that is required is that an agreement in writing signed by the transferor can be gathered from the evidence.

anchor.surface_text: A formal lease is number necessary to attract the application of S. 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act. All that is required is that an agreement in writing signed by the transferor can be gath- ered from the evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text requires only 'writing signed... from which terms... ascertained'; correspondence/Ex181 suffices.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to consider and decide all the points urged [including plaintiff's title] because the Assistant Judge was right on sec. 53-A.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was elaborately argued before us by the learned companynsel for the parties, but in our view, it is number necessary to companysider and decide all the points urged because we companysider that the Assistant Judge was right...

holdings.reasoning_summary: S53A plea sufficient to dispose case; no need for plaintiff's title.
